column4:
Introduction

Note: This programme is only available as a top-up programme and entry is only available to Year 4.

Economics affects all our daily lives. It is about how society makes choices when faced with limited resources. You will learn about the major issues facing the world today. Should the UK join the Euro? How should we finance our higher education and health systems? How can poverty in the Third World be reduced? Can inner cities be regenerated? All of these questions can only be answered through sound economic analysis.

The programme offers students the opportunity to build on previous study of microeconomics, macroeconomics, political economy, quantitative methods. The core course in Modelling and Forecasting complements the research skills acquired through writing an honours project. Students can apply these skills to a range of options chosen from transport economics, international trade, European integration and regional and local economic development. Studying Economics at Abertay will prove to be a winning choice because of the high quality learning and teaching environment. Members of staff of the Division of Economics, located within the Dundee Business School, are academically very qualified in terms of the possession of teaching and learning qualifications, experience of teaching, possession of post-graduate degrees and in terms of scholarly and research activities. The Quality Assurance Agency (QAA) rated the Division of Economics in 2001 as commendable for teaching and learning; commendable for student progression; and commendable for learning resources. Students are also provided with a supportive and inclusive learning environment.

What you study

Stage 4
Honours Dissertation, Economic Modelling and Forecasting, International Trade, Transport Economics, Economics of Education, International Finance, Regional and Local Economic Development, Europe and the Challenge of the 21st Century.

Core Themes

A Good Foundation â Microeconomics and macroeconomics, the two main branches of economics, are the springboard to more advanced studies. You are introduced to essential quantitative, IT and oral and written communication skills, and you appraise the role of economics in wider social and political issues through your study of political economy.

Sound Principles - Microeconomics teaches you how businesses compete and make economic decisions such as pricing and advertising. Macroeconomics looks at the performance of the whole economy, and you consider issues such as economic growth, unemployment, inflation and trade.
Choice of Applications â Options offered in fourth year include â transport, education, the environment, public choice, international finance, corporate finance, public finance, technological change, international trade and European integration. In your fourth (Honours) year you choose your own final project to be written over two semesters.

Key Career Enhancing Skills â At Abertay we are particularly good at teaching the essential quantitative, IT and communicative skills which employers are looking for when you apply for jobs. In this programme you learn to use and analyse statistics; to test economic models, and to forecast future economic trends using up-to-date econometric software such as EVIEWS.

Career Opportunities:

Economics graduates of the University of Abertay have undertaken positions in such diverse fields such as economic policy analysis for the Scottish Executive, lecturing at Universities, stock broking, financial analysis, purchasing, retailing, local government administration, banking and management.

column2: SQA HigherThis is a top up course available for direct entry to Year 4.

Minimum EntryFor further information on appropriate entrance qualifications, please email the Student Recruitment Office: sro@abertay.ac.uk

MatureIn order to determine an applicant's ability to benefit from study or research at the University of Abertay Dundee, a range of standard and flexible criteria will be used in considering applications.

In most circumstances applications will be considered in light of the following:

Applications from mature students are assessed on the same criteria outlined above i.e. a minimum of Higher National Certificate for direct entry to Year 2. For those without standard entry qualifications, consideration is given to experience gained as well as professional qualifications and other forms of learning that could provide evidence of ability to benefit from a particular course.

The successful completion of approved Higher National courses eg Higher National Certificate (HNC) or Higher National Diploma (HND) provides significant evidence of ability to benefit from study at Abertay.

For further advice please use our Got a Question section.

OverseasThe University makes offers of entry to courses based on qualifications offered worldwide.
All applicants are required to provide certified proof of competence in English Language. The University's minimum requirements are IELTS 6.0 (with no band lower than 5.0), TOEFL CBT 223, TOEFL 563, TOEFL IBT 85 or a suitable equivalent qualification.

column4:
Transferable skills

While studying on this course you will gain a number of practical skills that are useful in any field of business, such as how to use email, type reports, build a database and use the internet effectively as well as being introduced to specialised software relevant to your subject choices. You will also learn how to sift through vast quantities of detailed information quickly, and to present the important points in a concise and straightforward manner. As you progress through the degree course, you will gain other incidental skills which will prove invaluable in any future working environment. These may include:
1. Learning how to learn effectively
2. Self-motivation
3. Assertiveness
4. Time management
5. Meeting deadlines
6. Problem solving
7. Analysis, synthesis, discrimination and judgement
8. Logical and reasoned thinking.

Teamwork

Being able to work as a member of a team is an important quality in a University student. Working in a team situation allows you to utilise your own personal strengths and to build upon areas where you are lacking by learning from other people. It also allows you to gain experience in leading discussions and delegating responsibility, as well as learning to become an effective listener â an important leadership quality which can sometimes be overlooked. Making a positive contribution to a joint project enables you to develop team-working skills.
Working together on coursework often allows you to form close friendships in your social life as you learn to listen to and trust other peopleâs judgements.
